declarations.comments:
Type for failures while decoding, a path to the point in the JSON that failure occurred, a
message describing the problem, and a list of further causes for the failure.
declarations.title: DecodeError

declarations.comments: Prints an `DecodeError` as a somewhat readable error message.
declarations.title: print

declarations.comments:
Updates the path for an error. The transformation is applied to the error itself along with
its causes, recursively. This is intended for extending the path to elaborate on the location
of errors from the top down.
declarations.title: withPath

declarations.comments:
Starts a new context for the error, pushing the current error into `causes` and providing a
new message. This is useful for cases where you want to introduce a higher level error, adding
information about domain types, for example.
declarations.title: withContext

declarations.comments: Constructs an error from a path and message (no further causes).
declarations.title: error

declarations.comments: Constructs a basic error from just a message.
declarations.title: basic

declarations.comments: Constructs an error with the message "No value found" and the specified path.
declarations.title: noValueFound

declarations.comments: Codec type for `Json` values.
declarations.title: Codec

declarations.comments: Encodes a value as JSON using the specified code.
declarations.title: encode

declarations.comments: Tries to decode JSON to a value using the specified code.
declarations.title: decode

declarations.comments: The "identity codec" for `Json` values.
declarations.title: json

declarations.comments: A codec for `null` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: null

declarations.comments: A codec for `Boolean` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: boolean

declarations.comments: A codec for `Number` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: number

declarations.comments: A codec for `Int` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: int

declarations.comments: A codec for `String` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: string

declarations.comments: A codec for `Codepoint` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: codePoint

declarations.comments: A codec for `Char` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: char

declarations.comments:
A codec for `JArray` values in `Json`. This does not decode the values of the array, for that
use `array` for a general array decoder, or `indexedArray` with `index` to decode fixed length
array encodings.
declarations.title: jarray

declarations.comments: A codec for `JObject` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: jobject

declarations.comments: A codec for `Void` values.
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
A codec for arbitrary length `Array`s where every item in the array
shares the same type.

``` purescript
import Data.Codec.JSON as CJ

codecIntArray ∷ CJ.Codec (Array Int)
codecIntArray = CJ.array CJ.int
```
declarations.title: array

declarations.comments: Codec type for specifically indexed `JArray` elements.
declarations.title: IndexedCodec

declarations.comments:
A codec for types that are encoded as an array with a specific layout.

For example, if we'd like to encode a `Person` as a 2-element array, like
`["Rashida", 37]`, we could write the following codec:

```purescript
import Data.Codec.JSON ((~))
import Data.Codec.JSON as CJ

type Person = { name ∷ String, age ∷ Int }

codecPerson ∷ CJ.Codec Person
codecPerson = CJ.indexedArray $
  { name: _, age: _ }
    <$> _.name ~ CJ.index 0 CJ.string
    <*> _.age ~ CJ.index 1 CJ.int
```
declarations.title: indexedArray

declarations.comments: A codec for an item in an `indexedArray`.
declarations.title: index

declarations.comments: Codec type for `JObject` prop/value pairs.
declarations.title: PropCodec

declarations.comments:
A codec for objects that are encoded with specific properties.

See also `Data.Codec.JSON.Record.object` for a more commonly useful
version of this function.
declarations.title: object

declarations.comments: A codec for a property of an object.
declarations.title: prop

declarations.comments:
The starting value for a object-record codec. Used with `recordProp` it
provides a convenient method for defining codecs for record types that
encode into JSON objects of the same shape.

For example, to encode a record as the JSON object
`{ "name": "Karl", "age": 25 }` we would define a codec like this:
```
import Data.Codec.JSON as CJ
import Type.Proxy (Proxy(..))

type Person = { name ∷ String, age ∷ Int }

codecPerson ∷ CJ.Codec Person
codecPerson =
  CJ.object $ CJ.record
    # CJ.recordProp (Proxy :: _ "name") CJ.string
    # CJ.recordProp (Proxy :: _ "age") CJ.int
```

See also `Data.Codec.JSON.Record.object` for a more commonly useful
version of this function.
declarations.title: record

declarations.comments:
Used with `record` to define codecs for record types that encode into JSON
objects of the same shape. See the comment on `record` for an example.
declarations.title: recordProp

declarations.comments:
Used with `record` to define an optional field.

This will only decode the property as `Nothing` if the field does not exist
in the object - having a values such as `null` assigned will need handling
separately.

The property will be omitted when encoding and the value is `Nothing`.
declarations.title: recordPropOptional

declarations.comments:
A codec for JSON values that can be `null` or some other value.

This should not be used if an accurate representation of nested `Maybe` values is required, as
values like `Just Nothing` cannot be encoded. For nested `Maybe`s consider using
`Data.Codec.JSON.Common.maybe` instead.
declarations.title: nullable

declarations.comments:
A codec for introducing names into error messages - useful when definiting a codec for a type
synonym for a record, for instance.
declarations.title: named

declarations.comments:
A codec for types that can be safely coerced.

Accepts the name of the target type as an argument to improve error messaging when the inner
codec fails.
declarations.title: coercible

declarations.comments:
Adapts an existing codec with a pair of functions to allow a value to be
further refined. If the inner decoder fails an `UnexpectedValue` error will
be raised for JSON input.

This function is named as such as the pair of functions it accepts
correspond with the `preview` and `review` functions of a `Prism`-style lens.

An example of this would be a codec for `Data.String.NonEmpty.NonEmptyString`:

```purescript
nonEmptyString ∷ CJ.Codec NES.NonEmptyString
nonEmptyString = CJ.prismaticCodec "NonEmptyString" NES.fromString NES.toString CJ.string
```

Another example might be to handle a mapping from a small sum type to
strings:

```purescript
data Direction = North | South | West | East

directionCodec :: Codec Direction
directionCodec = CJ.prismaticCodec "Direction" dec enc string
  where
    dec = case _ of
      "N" -> Just North
      "S" -> Just South
      "W" -> Just West
      "E" -> Just East
      _ -> Nothing

    enc = case _ of
      North -> "N"
      South -> "S"
      West -> "W"
      East -> "E"
```

Although for this latter case there are some other options too, in the form
of `Data.Codec.JSON.Generic.nullarySum` and `Data.Codec.JSON.Sum.enumSum`.
declarations.title: prismaticCodec

declarations.comments:
Type for failures while decoding, a path to the point in the JSON that failure occurred, a
message describing the problem, and a list of further causes for the failure.
declarations.title: DecodeError

declarations.comments:
`Codec` is defined as a `Profunctor` so that `lcmap` can be used to target
specific fields when defining a codec for a product type. This operator
is a convenience for that:

``` purescript
tupleCodec =
  Tuple
    <$> fst ~ fstCodec
    <*> snd ~ sndCodec
```

A codec for `NonEmptyString` values.

Encodes as the standard type in JSON, but will fail to decode if the string is empty.
declarations.title: nonEmptyString

declarations.comments:
A codec for `NonEmptyArray` values.

Encodes as the standard type in JSON, but will fail to decode if the array is empty.
declarations.title: nonEmptyArray

declarations.comments: A codec for `Maybe` values.
declarations.title: maybe

declarations.comments:
A codec for `Tuple` values.

Encodes as a two-element array in JSON.
declarations.title: tuple

declarations.comments: A codec for `Either` values.
declarations.title: either

declarations.comments:
A codec for `List` values.

Encodes as an array in JSON.
declarations.title: list

declarations.comments:
A codec for `NonEmptyList` values.

Encodes as an array in JSON.
declarations.title: nonEmptyList

declarations.comments:
A codec for `Map` values.

Encodes as an array of two-element key/value arrays in JSON.
declarations.title: map

declarations.comments:
A codec for `Map` values which have string keys.

Encodes as an object in JSON.
declarations.title: strMap

declarations.comments:
A codec for `Set` values.

Encodes as an array in JSON.
declarations.title: set

declarations.comments:
A codec for `NonEmptySet` values.

Encodes as an array in JSON.
declarations.title: nonEmptySet

declarations.comments:
A codec for `Object` values.

Encodes as an array of two-element key/value arrays in JSON.
declarations.title: foreignObject

declarations.comments: Codec type for `JObject` prop/value pairs.
declarations.title: PropCodec

declarations.comments: Codec type for specifically indexed `JArray` elements.
declarations.title: IndexedCodec

declarations.comments:
Type for failures while decoding, a path to the point in the JSON that failure occurred, a
message describing the problem, and a list of further causes for the failure.
declarations.title: DecodeError

declarations.comments: Codec type for `Json` values.
declarations.title: Codec

declarations.comments: A codec for `Void` values.
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments: A codec for `String` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: string

declarations.comments:
Used with `record` to define an optional field.

This will only decode the property as `Nothing` if the field does not exist
in the object - having a values such as `null` assigned will need handling
separately.

The property will be omitted when encoding and the value is `Nothing`.
declarations.title: recordPropOptional

declarations.comments:
Used with `record` to define codecs for record types that encode into JSON
objects of the same shape. See the comment on `record` for an example.
declarations.title: recordProp

declarations.comments:
The starting value for a object-record codec. Used with `recordProp` it
provides a convenient method for defining codecs for record types that
encode into JSON objects of the same shape.

For example, to encode a record as the JSON object
`{ "name": "Karl", "age": 25 }` we would define a codec like this:
```
import Data.Codec.JSON as CJ
import Type.Proxy (Proxy(..))

type Person = { name ∷ String, age ∷ Int }

codecPerson ∷ CJ.Codec Person
codecPerson =
  CJ.object $ CJ.record
    # CJ.recordProp (Proxy :: _ "name") CJ.string
    # CJ.recordProp (Proxy :: _ "age") CJ.int
```

See also `Data.Codec.JSON.Record.object` for a more commonly useful
version of this function.
declarations.title: record

declarations.comments: A codec for a property of an object.
declarations.title: prop

declarations.comments:
Adapts an existing codec with a pair of functions to allow a value to be
further refined. If the inner decoder fails an `UnexpectedValue` error will
be raised for JSON input.

This function is named as such as the pair of functions it accepts
correspond with the `preview` and `review` functions of a `Prism`-style lens.

An example of this would be a codec for `Data.String.NonEmpty.NonEmptyString`:

```purescript
nonEmptyString ∷ CJ.Codec NES.NonEmptyString
nonEmptyString = CJ.prismaticCodec "NonEmptyString" NES.fromString NES.toString CJ.string
```

Another example might be to handle a mapping from a small sum type to
strings:

```purescript
data Direction = North | South | West | East

directionCodec :: Codec Direction
directionCodec = CJ.prismaticCodec "Direction" dec enc string
  where
    dec = case _ of
      "N" -> Just North
      "S" -> Just South
      "W" -> Just West
      "E" -> Just East
      _ -> Nothing

    enc = case _ of
      North -> "N"
      South -> "S"
      West -> "W"
      East -> "E"
```

Although for this latter case there are some other options too, in the form
of `Data.Codec.JSON.Generic.nullarySum` and `Data.Codec.JSON.Sum.enumSum`.
declarations.title: prismaticCodec

declarations.comments:
A codec for objects that are encoded with specific properties.

See also `Data.Codec.JSON.Record.object` for a more commonly useful
version of this function.
declarations.title: object

declarations.comments: A codec for `Number` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: number

declarations.comments:
A codec for JSON values that can be `null` or some other value.

This should not be used if an accurate representation of nested `Maybe` values is required, as
values like `Just Nothing` cannot be encoded. For nested `Maybe`s consider using
`Data.Codec.JSON.Common.maybe` instead.
declarations.title: nullable

declarations.comments: A codec for `null` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: null

declarations.comments:
A codec for introducing names into error messages - useful when definiting a codec for a type
synonym for a record, for instance.
declarations.title: named

declarations.comments: The "identity codec" for `Json` values.
declarations.title: json

declarations.comments: A codec for `JObject` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: jobject

declarations.comments:
A codec for `JArray` values in `Json`. This does not decode the values of the array, for that
use `array` for a general array decoder, or `indexedArray` with `index` to decode fixed length
array encodings.
declarations.title: jarray

declarations.comments: A codec for `Int` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: int

declarations.comments:
A codec for types that are encoded as an array with a specific layout.

For example, if we'd like to encode a `Person` as a 2-element array, like
`["Rashida", 37]`, we could write the following codec:

```purescript
import Data.Codec.JSON ((~))
import Data.Codec.JSON as CJ

type Person = { name ∷ String, age ∷ Int }

codecPerson ∷ CJ.Codec Person
codecPerson = CJ.indexedArray $
  { name: _, age: _ }
    <$> _.name ~ CJ.index 0 CJ.string
    <*> _.age ~ CJ.index 1 CJ.int
```
declarations.title: indexedArray

declarations.comments: A codec for an item in an `indexedArray`.
declarations.title: index

declarations.comments: Encodes a value as JSON using the specified code.
declarations.title: encode

declarations.comments: Tries to decode JSON to a value using the specified code.
declarations.title: decode

declarations.comments:
A codec for types that can be safely coerced.

Accepts the name of the target type as an argument to improve error messaging when the inner
codec fails.
declarations.title: coercible

declarations.comments: A codec for `Codepoint` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: codePoint

declarations.comments: A codec for `Char` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: char

declarations.comments: A codec for `Boolean` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: boolean

declarations.comments:
A codec for arbitrary length `Array`s where every item in the array
shares the same type.

``` purescript
import Data.Codec.JSON as CJ

codecIntArray ∷ CJ.Codec (Array Int)
codecIntArray = CJ.array CJ.int
```
declarations.title: array

declarations.comments:
`Codec` is defined as a `Profunctor` so that `lcmap` can be used to target
specific fields when defining a codec for a product type. This operator
is a convenience for that:

``` purescript
tupleCodec =
  Tuple
    <$> fst ~ fstCodec
    <*> snd ~ sndCodec
```

A helper for defining JSON codecs for sum types. To ensure exhaustivity
there needs to be a mapping to and from a tag type for the type to be
encoded.

- The first argument is the name of the type being decoded, for error
  message purposes.
- The second argument maps a tag value to a string to use in the encoding.
- The third argument maps a string back to a tag value during decoding.
- The fourth argument returns either a constant value or a decoder function
  based on a tag value.
- The fifth argument returns a tag value and optional encoded value to
  store for a constructor of the sum.
declarations.title: taggedSum

declarations.comments:
Encodes nullary sums with a `Generic` instance as strings that match the constructor names.

```purescript
import JSON as J
import Data.Codec.JSON as CJ
import Data.Codec.JSON.Generic as CJG

data MySum = Ctor1 | Ctor2 | Ctor3
derive instance genericMySum ∷ Generic MySum _

CJ.encode (CJG.nullarySum "MySum") Ctor1 == J.fromString "Ctor1"
CJ.decode (CJG.nullarySum "MySum") (J.fromString "Ctor3") == Right Ctor3
```
declarations.title: nullarySum
object

declarations.comments:
Constructs a `JPropCodec` for a `Record` from a record of codecs. Commonly
the `object` function in this module will be the preferred choice, as that
produces a `Codec` instead.
declarations.title: record

declarations.comments:
Used to wrap codec values provided in `record` to indicate the field is optional.

This will only decode the property as `Nothing` if the field does not exist
in the object - having a values such as `null` assigned will need handling
separately.

The property will be omitted when encoding and the value is `Nothing`.
declarations.title: Optional

declarations.comments: A lowercase alias for `Optional`, provided for stylistic reasons only.
declarations.title: optional

declarations.comments:
The class used to enable the building of `Record` codecs by providing a
record of codecs.
declarations.title: RowListCodec

declarations.comments:
A helper for defining JSON codecs for sum types. To ensure exhaustivity
there needs to be a mapping to and from a tag type for the type to be
encoded.

- The first argument is the name of the type being decoded, for error
  message purposes.
- The second argument maps a tag value to a string to use in the encoding.
- The third argument maps a string back to a tag value during decoding.
- The fourth argument returns either a constant value or a decoder function
  based on a tag value.
- The fifth argument returns a tag value and optional encoded value to
  store for a constructor of the sum.
declarations.title: taggedSum

declarations.comments:
Builds a codec for a variant from a record, similar to the way
`Variant.match` works to pattern match on a variant.

Commonly used to write decoders for sum-types, by providing a mapping from
and to a Variant from that type and then using `dimap`.

Each field in the record accepts an `Either`, where `Right` is used to
specify a codec used for the constructor, and `Left` is used to specify a
static value (generally as `Left unit` for nullary constructors).

The variant will be encoded as a JSON object of the form
`{ "tag": <name>, "value": <value> }`, where `<name>` is the name of the
variant case, and `<value>` is the associated value (omitted in the case
of static `Left`-defined values).

```purescript
codecMaybeMatch ∷ ∀ a. CJ.Codec a → CJ.Codec (Maybe a)
codecMaybeMatch codecA =
  dimap toVariant fromVariant
    (CJV.variantMatch
      { just: Right codecA
      , nothing: Left unit
      })
  where
  toVariant = case _ of
    Just a → V.inj (Proxy ∷ _ "just") a
    Nothing → V.inj (Proxy ∷ _ "nothing") unit
  fromVariant = V.match
    { just: Just
    , nothing: \_ → Nothing
    }
```
declarations.title: variantMatch

declarations.comments:
Builds codecs for variants in combination with `variantCase`.

Provides an alternative means of building variant codecs to that of
`variantMatch`, often for cases where the codec is being constructed
with a fold or some other similar technique.

```purescript
codecMaybe ∷ ∀ a. CJ.Codec a → CJ.Codec (Maybe a)
codecMaybe codecA =
  dimap toVariant fromVariant
    (CJV.variant
      # CJV.variantCase _Just (Right codecA)
      # CJV.variantCase _Nothing (Left unit))
  where
  toVariant = case _ of
    Just a → V.inj _Just a
    Nothing → V.inj _Nothing unit
  fromVariant = V.case_
    # V.on _Just Just
    # V.on _Nothing (const Nothing)
  _Just = Proxy ∷ Proxy "just"
  _Nothing = Proxy ∷ Proxy "nothing"
```
declarations.title: variant

declarations.comments:
The class used to enable the building of `Variant` codecs from a record of
codecs.
declarations.title: VariantCodec
